commit_message:
blueprint: l23network-refactror-to-provider-based-resources

Change-Id: Ib9c8471adb24549f32cfbc1672c25210e5d9cd89
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/58/141858/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Make all L23network resources provider-based ============================================ Related links: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/fuel/+spec/l23network-refactror-to-provider-based-resources * https://docs.google.com/a/mirantis.com/document/d/1QVoexrDF_MS92IZd4jnwPWQDxTAWMzUUrcMyu8VjGF4/edit#heading=h.n2krytstn2p Problem description =================== L23network puppet module using in FUEL for managing network configuration for Openvswitch, native linux L2 network stack and L3 network parameters for NICs. At this moment only Openvswitch part made as provider based. I propose refactor this module for achive following aims: * unify, and make provider-agnostic configuration options for all network resources (not only Openvswitch) * make l23network resources pluggable by provider-based puppet way. As demo, we can made Contrail or OpenDaylight plugin. * improve possibility of combine different provider to the one composite network scheme. Proposed change =============== L2::Bridge ---------- L2::Port -------- L2::Bond -------- It's a special type of port. Designed for bonding two or more interfaces. L2::Patch --------- It's a special type of port. Designed for connect bridges inside one physical host to one L2 virtual network segment. .. code-block:: puppet l23network::l2::patch { 'br1-to-br2': bridges => ['br1', 'br2'], ports => ['br1-xxx1', 'br2-xxx2'], # patchcord jack's names vlan_ids => [0,0], # vlan IDs for each jack provider => lnx # (or ovs) } For OVS provider this resource will be implemented as native "patch" interface type. For LNX -- as veth pair, where interfaces inserted to corresponded bridges as tagged or not ports. L2::Tunnel ---------- It's a special type of port. Designed for connect bridges on different nodes to one L2 virtual network segment. It looks like L2::Patch resource. .. code-block:: puppet l23network::l2::tunnel { 'tun-to-node2': peer => ".....", bridge => 'br1', port => 'br1-xxx1', vlan_ids => 0, type => gre, # (or vxlan) provider => lnx } Will be supported following types of TUNs: * Point-to-point GRE TUN * Point-to-point VXLAN TUN * Multicast group based VXLAN L3::Ifconfig ------------ Alternatives ------------ Leave it as-is. This will limit our ability to deploy configure some specific vendor-based solutions, that incompotible with open vSwitsh. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- Backward compatibility will achived by API versioning. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- List of supporting operation systems will be extended. New OSes can be added by plugin. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * Sergey Vasilenko (xenolog) <svasilenko@mirantis.com> Other contributors: * Stanislaw Bogatkin (sbogatkin) <sbogatkin@mirantis.com> * Dmitry Ilyin (idv1985) <dilyin@mirantis.com> * Andrey Danin (adanin) <adanin@mirantis.com> Work Items ---------- * Make low-level L2 network resources provider-based * Make support for GRE/vxlan tunneling * Make L3 network resources provider-based * Support frequencely used SDN as plugin Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= We will need to improve devops to support emulating multiple L2 domains so that systems tests can be run using this topology. Also will be better implement test cases for periodically run ones on bare-metal lab. Documentation Impact ==================== Current documentation will has not lage changes, because network_scheme interface shouldn't be changed. But this refactoring give us pluggability. L23network plugin how-to should be written/published. References ========== * Transformations. How it work: https://docs.google.com/a/mirantis.com/document/d/1QVoexrDF_MS92IZd4jnwPWQDxTAWMzUUrcMyu8VjGF4/edit#heading=h.n2krytstn2p

Package tags are mutable, so it's type should be a list everywhere

commit_message:
Plugins info report added

Plugins info can't be added into clusters report due to
plugins are stored as list in the cluster, so additional
report is required.
Plugins report is available by url: /api/v1/csv/plugins

Change-Id: Ia19d4578cb836438573dd1a494b54d1772f61b5d
Closes-Bug: #1431362

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import csv import flask import mock import six import types from fuel_analytics.test.api.resources.utils.inst_structure_test import \ InstStructureTest from fuel_analytics.test.base import DbTest from fuel_analytics.api.app import app from fuel_analytics.api.resources.utils.stats_to_csv import StatsToCsv class PluginsToCsvExportTest(InstStructureTest, DbTest): def test_get_plugin_keys_paths(self): exporter = StatsToCsv() _, _, _, csv_keys_paths = exporter.get_plugin_keys_paths() self.assertTrue(['cluster_id' in csv_keys_paths]) self.assertTrue(['master_node_uid' in csv_keys_paths]) self.assertTrue(['name' in csv_keys_paths]) self.assertTrue(['version' in csv_keys_paths]) self.assertTrue(['fuel_version' in csv_keys_paths]) self.assertTrue(['package_version' in csv_keys_paths]) def test_get_flatten_plugins(self): installations_num = 10 inst_structures = self.get_saved_inst_structures( installations_num=installations_num) exporter = StatsToCsv() structure_paths, cluster_paths, plugins_paths, csv_paths = \ exporter.get_plugin_keys_paths() flatten_plugins = exporter.get_flatten_plugins( structure_paths, cluster_paths, plugins_paths, inst_structures) self.assertTrue(isinstance(flatten_plugins, types.GeneratorType)) pos_mn_uid = csv_paths.index(['master_node_uid']) pos_cluster_id = csv_paths.index(['cluster_id']) for flatten_plugin in flatten_plugins: self.assertIsNotNone(flatten_plugin[pos_mn_uid]) self.assertIsNotNone(flatten_plugin[pos_cluster_id]) self.assertEquals(len(csv_paths), len(flatten_plugin)) def test_export_plugins(self): installations_num = 100 exporter = StatsToCsv() with app.test_request_context(), mock.patch.object( flask.request, 'args', {'from_date': '2015-02-01'}): # Creating installation structures inst_structures = self.get_saved_inst_structures( installations_num=installations_num) # Filtering installation structures result = exporter.export_plugins(inst_structures) self.assertTrue(isinstance(result, types.GeneratorType)) output = six.StringIO(list(result)) reader = csv.reader(output) for _ in reader: pass

commit_message:
Updating functionality for action logs changed

The main reason this patch is introduced - issue with two Nailgun tasks:
check_networks and verify_networks which are constructed from the same
instance of task object. This in turn leads to dublication of particular
attributes in action_logs entries and so affects update routines for
them. Also check_networks is not updated to status "ready" in case of
success so action logs processing methods are changed to deal with this
issue.

Change-Id: I949eec203b629ef6d1d0d6664540c404dc12c36c
Closes-Bug: #1430812
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/00/163900/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Introduce External IPAM Interface

This introduces an interface for an external IPAM driver.  Neutron needs to be
modified to make calls using it for its IPAM needs.  Additionally, the default
IPAM interface must be written to implement this interface.

Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ipam

Change-Id: Ieb565a2d2629ab8236a4be1173df464b7aa06f04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/39/134339/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 OpenStack LLC. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import abc # TODO(Carl) How to make this API asynchronous? I can think of a number of # ways. I'd like to hear your suggestions. class IPAMDriver(object): """Interface definition for an IPAM driver. There should be an instance of the driver for every scope. Previous to the introduction of a formal IPAM interface, the scope was implicit. It was assumed that each tenant owned its own IPv4 address scope. NAT is needed when routing across address scopes if allowed at all (e.g. allowed between tenants and "external networks" and not allowed between tenants). With IPv4, overlapping addresses is needed. With IPv6, we'd like to avoid overlap, even between scopes. However, scopes are still useful for routing. For example, if you are a tenant in a shared datacenter, the admin should set up an address scope from which addresses/subnets can be allocated in order to be routable on an "external network." Incidentally, I don't think that Neutron should enforce uniqueness of addresses for IPv6 like in the case of ULA. However, proper methods (from RFCs) should be used to generate ULA addresses to avoid conflict. An address scope has a range of addresses which are available for allocation. The implicit tenant IPv4 address scopes should include *all* possible addresses. The IPv6 implicit scope might be a little more limiting (e.g. ULA addresses, global unicast, etc) but maybe not. """ __meta__ = abc.ABCMeta ADDRESS_TYPE_IPV4 = '4' ADDRESS_TYPE_IPV6 = '6' # Does this fit? Should we save this for later? Create a separate L2 # specific interface? The semantics of L2 address scoping and assignment # are very different. However, in its essense, a MAC is just another # address, which is a number. I'll see if I can make the API generic # enough for L2 addressing but no promises. Of course, the use of netaddr # assumes IP in this straw man. I'm sure something equivalent could be # created. ADDRESS_TYPE_MAC = 'MAC' @staticmethod def get_driver(scope, address_type): """Returns an instance of the configured IPAM driver TODO(Carl) How does the address range and minimum and maximum allocation size get allocated? I think that might be a subject for future development work. For now, the implicit scopes are unrestricted in this sense and I think it might take an API change to add control over these when subnet allocations are fully supported. This is out of the scope for now. TODO(Carl) Flag to enforce uniqueness of subnets within the scope. Default is off to support current operation. :param scope: An identifier for the address space to use. For now, pass the id for the tenant owning the scope. :returns: An instance of IPAMDriver for the given scope """ raise NotImplementedError("This is an API preview. It doesn't work yet.") @abc.abstractmethod def get_subnet(identifier, owner, subnet, allocation_pools=None): """Gets a subnet, allocating it if necessary The initial reference implementation will probably just allow any allocation, even overlapping ones. This can be expanded on by future blueprints. :param identifier: The identifier for the subnet. It must be unique within the address scope and *should* be globally unique. :param owner: An identifier for the owner of this subnet. This is really an opaque identifier from IPAM's point of view. TODO(Carl) I don't know yet how this will be used. Maybe I'll remove it. Maybe the identifier is all that is needed. :param subnet: A netaddr.IPNetwork representing the address space requested. :param allocation_pools: A list of netaddr.IPRange representing the addresses available for free allocation. The default is the entire set of normally useable addresses in the subnet (i.e. excludes network and broadcast addresses). By default, the allocator may allow allocating addresses outside of this range if specifically requested. :returns: An instance of IPAMSubnet :raises: IPAMAlreadyAllocated """ raise NotImplementedError() @abc.abstractmethod def get_subnet_by_size(identifier, owner, prefixlen, allocation_pools=None): """Gets a subnet of the given prefixlen, allocating it if necessary The initial reference implementation will probably not implement this since current Neutron requires the user to specify the addresses. An API change/extension will be needed to allow requesting a subnet of a certain size. :param identifier: The identifier for the subnet. It must be unique within the address scope and *should* be globally unique. :param owner: An identifier for the owner of this subnet. This is really an opaque identifier from IPAM's point of view. TODO(Carl) I don't know yet how this will be used. Maybe I'll remove it. Maybe the identifier is all that is needed. :param prefixlen: An integer that is the prefix len requested. Must be within the min and max allowed. :param allocation_pools: Similar to same param in get_subnet method. addresses available for free allocation. The default is the entire set of normally useable addresses in the subnet (i.e. excludes network and broadcast addresses). By default, the allocator may allow allocating addresses outside of this range if specifically requested. :returns: An instance of IPAMSubnet :raises: IPAMAlreadyAllocated """ raise NotImplementedError() @abc.abstractmethod def remove_subnet(identifier): """Removes an allocation The initial reference implementation will probably do nothing. :param identifier: The identifier of the subnet to remove :returns: None :raises: IPAMAllocationNotFound """ raise NotImplementedError() @abc.abstractmethod def get_allocations(): """Returns a set of all current allocations TODO(Carl) Is this useful? :returns: set of IPAMSubnets """ @abc.abstractmethod def get_ranges(): """Returns the available address ranges defined for this scope The initial reference implementation will probably return the entire IP address space since current Neutron doesn't restrict it at all within a scope. :returns: A list of netaddr.IPRange """ raise NotImplementedError() @abc.abstractmethod def get_minmax_prefixlen(): """Return the min and max prefixlens that can be allocated The initial reference implementation will probably return something like (8, 30) for IPv4 and something similarly unrestrictive for IPv6. :returns: A tuple with the min and max prefix lengths Keep in mind that a small prefix size means a larger subnet. """ raise NotImplementedError() class IPAMSubnet(object): """Interface definition for an IPAM subnet An IPAM subnet would typically be associated with a network but may not be. It could represent a dynamically routed IP address space in which case the normal network and broadcast addresses would be useable. It should always be a routable block of addresses and representable in CIDR notation. The subnet has an allocation pool which is the set of addresses which can be allocated. The subnet may or may not be able to allocate a requested addresses outside of this pool depending on the driver and configuration. """ @abc.abstractmethod def allocate(identifier, address=None): """Allocates an IP address :param identifier: The identifier for this allocation. It is an opaque identifier from IPAM's point of view. However, it might mean something more to the caller. TODO(Carl) Should the address just be its own identifier. Might take this out but wanted to leave it in the straw man. :param address: A netaddr.IPAddress representing the address requested or None to allocate from the pool. :raises: IPAMAlreadyAllocated """ raise NotImplementedError() @abc.abstractmethod def deallocate(identifier, address): """Returns a previously allocated address to the pool :param identifier: (See the allocate method) :param address: A netaddr.IPAddress :returns: None :raises: IPAMAllocationNotFound """ raise NotImplementedError()

Change some comments for instance param

The existing comments on instance object is wrong.
This patch changed some of the in compute layer.

Change-Id: Ib19e1a656202f6daa8cca74a864a862788196750

subject: Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-13 14:38:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/f7ae91cad1cad1b890804cc86e31ee4a169a3eac', 'message': 'Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Change-Id: I9cac7808fe64d612ea2d5d6e3ec63fb1b56860de
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-01-14 14:27:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/5e9f2676c979c993ff40f1f1a040930a165b874e', 'message': "Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Some keynotes on the change:

* We need to run nailgun in privileged mode, because its puppet tries to
  change kernel's listen queue.
* exec_cmd_in_container runs dockerctl now, in order to be compatible
  with dockers before 1.3 (before docker exec).
* db_backup_timeout was increased, because containers were shutdown
  befor docker package updating and we need to wait until they run
  again.

Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade

Change-Id: I9cac7808fe64d612ea2d5d6e3ec63fb1b56860de
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-01-21 17:55:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/cd5b227346b3b649de8ef57733bb8799cc55b84b', 'message': "Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Some keynotes on the change:

* We need to run nailgun in privileged mode, because its puppet tries to
  change kernel's listen queue.
* We need to recreate nailgun container in privileged mode (before
  upgrade) since docker >= 0.11 requres it.
* The exec_cmd_in_container runs dockerctl now, in order to be compatible
  with dockers before 1.3 (before docker exec).
* The host_system engine runs fuel verifier now, since containers have
  been stopped after docker upgrading and we need to wait until they up.

Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade

Change-Id: I9cac7808fe64d612ea2d5d6e3ec63fb1b56860de
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-01-22 13:38:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/d8670d7208d1a146a1633b68f9afeb47efce0f42', 'message': "Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Some keynotes on the change:

* We need to run nailgun in privileged mode, because its puppet tries to
  change kernel's listen queue.
* We need to recreate nailgun container in privileged mode (before
  upgrade) since docker >= 0.11 requres it.
* The exec_cmd_in_container runs dockerctl now, in order to be compatible
  with dockers before 1.3 (before docker exec).
* The host_system engine runs fuel verifier now, since containers have
  been stopped after docker upgrading and we need to wait until they up.
* db_backup_timeout was increased, because containers were shutdown
  befor docker package updating and we need to wait until postgre
  service up again.

Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade

Change-Id: I9cac7808fe64d612ea2d5d6e3ec63fb1b56860de

"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-01-26 10:15:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/30a8b02789528ecc9b7d6b44f1b1d1ec432cff8d', 'message': "Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Some keynotes on the change:

* We need to run nailgun in privileged mode, because its puppet tries to
  change kernel's listen queue.
* We need to recreate nailgun container in privileged mode (before
  upgrade) since docker >= 0.11 requres it.
* The exec_cmd_in_container runs dockerctl now, in order to be compatible
  with dockers before 1.3 (before docker exec).
* The host_system engine runs fuel verifier now, since containers have
  been stopped after docker upgrading and we need to wait until they up.
* db_backup_timeout was increased, because containers were shutdown
  befor docker package updating and we need to wait until postgre

commit_message:
Use --net=host for containers, remove cobbler hack

Some keynotes on the change:

* We need to run nailgun in privileged mode, because its puppet tries to
  change kernel's listen queue.
* We need to recreate nailgun container in privileged mode (before
  upgrade) since docker >= 0.11 requres it.
* We need to move supervisor's dhcrelay.conf into versioned folder,
  because it shouldn't run in 6.1.
* The exec_cmd_in_container runs dockerctl now, in order to be compatible
  with dockers before 1.3 (before docker exec).
* The host_system engine runs fuel verifier now, since containers have
  been stopped after docker upgrading and we need to wait until they up.
* db_backup_timeout was increased, because containers were shutdown
  befor docker package updating and we need to wait until postgre
  service up again.

Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
Implements: blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade

Change-Id: I9cac7808fe64d612ea2d5d6e3ec63fb1b56860de

commit_message:
Enhance Mgmt-Show To Support Deleted Instances

introduce ?deleted=true parameter to /mgmt/instances/<uuid> to show
the instance whether it's deleted or not.

Change-Id: I14e10a4abd5188ad49299205772a340ecf46143a
Co-Authored-By: Nikhil Manchanda <SlickNik@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint mgmt-show-deleted

commit_message:
Remove default routes via hapr-p/hapr-m in haproxy ns

We no longer need those default routes and iptables marking/nat,
since we have 'hapr-ns' interface and default route via it, which
provides connectivity to other networks from haproxy namespace.

Change-Id: I67dbbbb1dcd61a201b697029d84a54679cc61018
Closes-bug: #1433150

commit_message:
Run docker containers with host networking

Note: Requires Docker 1.2 or greater.

This change removes the need for dhcrelay
for cobbler container and the configuration
of masquerade ip forward rules. It will be
left installed in case of rollback to a
previous Fuel release.

Changes LXC driver to native exec driver
libcontainer. shell command now uses docker
exec command instead of lxc-attach.

Added privileged mode to nailgun container which
is necessary for sysctl to operate with host
networking mode.

Removed link from nailgun to mcollective because
it is not needed any longer.

blueprint fuel-master-docker-host-networking
blueprint fuel-master-docker-upgrade

Change-Id: I4111caf9ac7b33c514481704b3fb253966759748
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/59/121559/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: base_opts="-t --net=host"
deleted_lines: base_opts="-t"

subject: Keep revoke tokens in SQL Database
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-17 19:15:47.000000000', 'files': ['deployment/puppet/openstack/manifests/keystone.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/1d5d0e721ef23481b33b5ba52f0e9173b8e1a9b6', 'message': 'Keep revoke tokens in SQL Database

Keep list of revoked tokens in SQL Database instead of memcache. In case
when memcached server is restarted so revokation list is lost.
Potentially, it allows to get access of invalidated token until they are
expired.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1433271
Related-Bug: 1425559

Change-Id: I36026ae9c91b320720c30e62d6f0f507ba04a96e
'}]
commit_message:
Keep revoke tokens in SQL Database

Keep list of revoked tokens in SQL Database instead of memcache. In case
when memcached server is restarted so revokation list is lost.
Potentially, it allows to get access of invalidated token until they are
expired.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: 1433271
Related-Bug: 1425559

Change-Id: I36026ae9c91b320720c30e62d6f0f507ba04a96e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/90/165190/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'revoke/driver': value => 'keystone.contrib.revoke.backends.sql.Revoke';

commit_message:
FIX: "disable offloading" flag functionality

Old network configuration
(6.0 and early) has global flag for disabling offload.

New implementation has 'disable offloading' flag per interface.
This commit add default set of ethtool propertios for disabling
offloading if no ethtool properties given for corresponded interface

Change-Id: Ic1aab4a6cfd32a3211d9a5c449ba887b7dc05953
Closes-bug: #1431735
Partial-bug: #1431396
Blueprint: refactor-l23-linux-bridges
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/50/164450/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def self.default_offload_set { 'generic-receive-offload' => false, 'generic-segmentation-offload' => false } end def self.correct_ethtool_set(prop_hash) if (!prop_hash.has_key?('ethtool') or prop_hash['ethtool'].empty?) \ and (prop_hash.has_key?('vendor_specific') and prop_hash['vendor_specific']['disable_offloading']) # add default offload settings if: # * no ethtool properties given # * "disable offload" flag given rv = {}.merge prop_hash rv['ethtool'] ||= {} rv['ethtool']['offload'] = default_offload_set() rv['vendor_specific'].delete('disable_offloading') else rv = prop_hash end return rv end resource_properties = L23network.correct_ethtool_set(resource_properties) resource_properties = L23network.correct_ethtool_set(resource_properties)

commit_message:
Add test for get_error_body

This function was not tested when first introduced. Tests check if it is
able to retrieve error body from HTTPError with response payload in json
or plaintext format.

Change-Id: I1b5c4da48d20a480718d38a2f0f6d904c168a1d2
Implements: blueprint re-thinking-fuel-client
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/27/161727/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import collections import jsonimport requests def test_get_error_body_get_from_json(self): ResponseMock = collections.namedtuple('ResponseMock', 'text') error_body = 'This is error body' exception = requests.HTTPError() exception.response = ResponseMock(text=json.dumps({ 'message': error_body })) self.assertEqual(error.get_error_body(exception), error_body) def test_get_error_body_get_from_plaintext(self): ResponseMock = collections.namedtuple('ResponseMock', 'text') error_body = 'This is error body' exception = requests.HTTPError() exception.response = ResponseMock(text=error_body) self.assertEqual(error.get_error_body(exception), error_body)

commit_message:
Remove not needed assert in randomly failing test

test_network_verification_neutron_with_vlan_segmentation was failing
randomly due to the task being in 'ready' state right after it was
called. Now it only checks if the task is eventually in 'ready' state,
which a good enought test case.

Change-Id: Ida5756facdbbe91d74404a4d12b4258d3ffdc470
Closes-Bug: #1427658

deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(task.status, 'running')

Versioned object - WatchRule and WatchData

Prototype implementation of oslo.versionedobjects.
This patch adds WatchRule and WatchData object.

Implements: blueprint versioned-objects

Co-Authored-By: ShaoHe Feng <shaohe.feng@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: He Jie Xu <hejie.xu@intel.com>
Co-Authored-By: Grzegorz Grasza <grzegorz.grasza@intel.com>

Change-Id: I29fc0fc99c0c425291246dc3889393cbcc0b82cf

commit_message:
Changed snapshot compress algoritm from gz to xz

The reason for this change is that
XZ archive is around two times smaller than GZIP

Related fuel-main patch: Ia35fb7294c85d0463860ca8af9812834522f5605

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ia8ba5d584ea97de4f476cb8bb632ca82baa76503
Closes-Bug: 1394487

subject: Use xz as compression tool for snapshot
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-19 12:08:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web/commit/315cf55aa86630191cff88cda00ac6f64f14001f', 'message': 'Use xz as compression tool for snapshot

Default compression level will: -3

Played with it on logs with ~6Gb of data

Snapshot compressed with:
- gzip takes: 479m Mb
- xz 3 level - 272 and takes 4 minutes
- xz 9 level - 239 and takes ~ 30 min

It is possible to use pixz utility that will run compressing
on multiple cores, but i dont think it is wise to depend on it,
because when master host will be installed on vm - it may take
very long time to generate snapshot

Change-Id: I84e66e92ebc20ceba2db98ff41f08b1fde323c0b
Closes-Bug: 1394487

commit_message:
Use xz as compression tool for snapshot

Default compression level will: -3

Played with it on logs with ~6Gb of data

Snapshot compressed with:
- gzip takes: 479m Mb
- xz 3 level - 272 and takes 4 minutes
- xz 9 level - 239 and takes ~ 30 min

It is possible to use pixz utility that will run compressing
on multiple cores, but i dont think it is wise to depend on it,
because when master host will be installed on vm - it may take
very long time to generate snapshot

DocImpact
Change-Id: I84e66e92ebc20ceba2db98ff41f08b1fde323c0b
Closes-Bug: 1394487
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/44/157344/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: compression_level: "-3"

commit_message:
Move reserve_block_device_name to nova.api

After failure of attaching volume with RPC problem,
unnecessary block_device_mapping of volume is recorded.
Because of this record, terminate_instance sometimes makes mistakes.
Volume that attached to another instance will be available from in-use.
This unnecessary record is caused by RPC problem, so move it to api
from compute.

Change-Id: I908e499b6c3bbe21441e60d92b9f671ccacb12b3
Closes-Bug: #1377161

commit_message:
Import updates to release_notes.py from oslo-incubator

During the time we started moving the script into this repository some
updates were made in the incubator. Port those updates here so the
latest version is available.

Change-Id: Ia8a4c1ef95755977a09f874b643d9c79bb86f5e8

added_lines: 'amped', 'jazzed', 'jubilant', 'psyched', 'stoked', 'tickled pink', parser.add_argument("--show-dates", action='store_true', default=False, help="show dates in the change log") # Get the python library/program name cmd = [sys.executable, 'setup.py', '--name'] stdout, stderr = run_cmd(cmd, cwd=library_path) library_name = stdout.strip() if args.show_dates: format = "--format=%h %ci %s" else: format = "--oneline" cmd = ["git", "log", "--no-color", format, "--no-merges", git_range] change_header = ["Changes in %s %s" % (library_name, git_range)]
deleted_lines: cmd = ["git", "log", "--no-color", "--oneline", "--no-merges", git_range] change_header = ["Changes in %s %s" % (library_path, git_range)]

commit_message:
Import release notes script from oslo-incubator

Move the release notes script from oslo-incubator to the release-tools
repository to make sharing it easier.

Change-Id: Icb1bb2d7954763f0afe86c7a73a99a26a31cbbcf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/65/161265/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: release_notes.py ---------------- This produces a set of release notes intended to be sent as an announcement email when a new library or package is produced. It is more suitable for libraries than for the major projects, because it includes a list of all of the changes and diff-stats output to show which files changed. The script parses the README.rst to find a line matching "``Bugs:``", extracts the URL following the colon, and includes that information in the output. The bugs URL is converted to a launchpad project URL and combined with the final version number to produce a *milestone* URL. The script uses ``python setup.py`` to determine the project name and the one-line description to include in the output text. Examples: ./release_notes.py ~/repos/openstack/oslo.config 1.7.0 1.8.0 Print the release notes between versions 1.7.0 and 1.8.0 for the project in the ``~/repos/openstack/oslo.config`` directory. ./release_notes.py --show-dates --changes-only ~/repos/openstack/oslo.config 1.8.0 HEAD Print the list of changes after 1.8.0 for the project in the ``~/repos/openstack/oslo.config`` directory, including the date of the change but leaving out the email message boilerplate. This mode is useful for examining the list of unreleased changes in a project to decide if a release is warranted and to pick a version number.

commit_message:
Add Gnocchi repository to Ceilometer

Gnocchi is a new datastore specialized into storing metrics and indexing
resources. It is going to be used by Ceilometer as its new (optional)
storage backend starting with the Kilo release.

Change-Id: I44c4592dd5bb8124684fc5c51632624f93469bc7

Add the bindep repo to Infrastructure Project

repo to the openstack-infra/ namespace pending TC approval.

section of projects.yaml.

commit_message:
[Launch Instance fix] Removing step number in Wizard widget

There are numbers for each step in the wizard widget navigation
column currently.  UX design has changed to not having those numbers,
so they should be removed.

Change-Id: Ibec174de35e99ea759e2d6cac6a1a4bf7e845760
Closes-Bug: 1433400

commit_message:
Update README to reflect state of the lxc module

The pull request in upstream Ansible was merged, so we should
communicate the most current state of the code.

Change-Id: I75614a51bd9d621c526254b814b562e7a63fb642
Closes-Bug: #1432438
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/69/165169/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * Our repository uses a custom `LXC` module which adds ``lxc:`` support to Ansible. The module within this repository is merged in upstream ansible at "https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras/pull/123", but not yet released.
deleted_lines: * Our repository uses a custom `LXC` module which adds ``lxc:`` support to Ansible. The module within this repository is presently pending in upstream ansible at "https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-extras/pull/123".

commit_message:
Move create-update-delete-stack-inplace test

Move to stable create-update-delete-stack-inplace test.
The test was broken because of bug in heat, so added
dependency on this bug.
The bug was actually related to updating of nested
stacks in heat. The new validation was added to heat
and it fails with validation error in some cases.

Change-Id: I8d0a5e4a8df202cdff57e0f7cceb804d470612aa
Depends-On: Ibb71f31f2ec7d1d37b995323a2474b799ea498bb

subject: Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_by_uuid
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-05 06:54:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/dc15e0d13c03975cd06548175a3e7f535ed98cc2', 'message': 'Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_by_uuid

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_by_uuid.

It is called by the follow function:
    add_fixed_ip_to_instance
    disassociate_network
    add_network_to_project
    associate
All of them have admin plolicy check.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: I2b75d0fe502aa27bf1c8994cdbac55ec173f70ed
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-03-10 07:03:38.000000000', 'files': ['nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e51a97906eb0afd187c7d6fc85123751772d3229', 'message': 'Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_by_uuid

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_by_uuid.

It is called by the follow function:
  1. network_api.get, context is elevated.
  2. delete_network, context is elevated.
  3. get_network, context is elevated.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: I2b75d0fe502aa27bf1c8994cdbac55ec173f70ed
'}]
commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_by_uuid

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_by_uuid.

It is called by the follow function:
  1. network_api.get, context is elevated.
  2. delete_network, context is elevated.
  3. get_network, context is elevated.

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: I2b75d0fe502aa27bf1c8994cdbac55ec173f70ed

commit_message:
FWaaS Insertion Model on Routers

Implementation for FWaaS insertion model to associate a Firewall
with specified Routers as opposed to the current model of association
with all Routers in the tenant.

- extension and new table tracking associated routers
- plugin changes to manage router association
- changes to plugin - agent interface (adding router associations)
- fw agent changes to pick up router associations from plugin
- UT changes
- Upgrade script

APIImpact
DocImpact

Change-Id: I0eba4b0aa127738397e6b9c45556e207216d79c7
Implements: blueprint fwaas-router-insertion

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import sqlalchemy as sa from neutron.db import model_base from neutron.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class Firewall_inserted_rtr(model_base.BASEV2): """Tracks FW on routers inserted""" __tablename__ = 'firewall_inserted_rtrs' fw_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('firewalls.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) router_id = sa.Column(sa.String(36), sa.ForeignKey('routers.id', ondelete="CASCADE"), primary_key=True) class Firewall_inserted_rtr_db_mixin(object): """Start with single router""" #TODO(sridar): start testing with single router model first def add_rtr_to_fw(self, context, fw): LOG.debug("add_router_to_fw() called") with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): fw_rtr_db = Firewall_inserted_rtr(fw_id=fw['id'], router_id=fw['router_id']) context.session.add(fw_rtr_db) def get_fw_rtrs(self, context, fwid): LOG.debug("get_fw_routers() called") with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): fw_rtr_qry = context.session.query(Firewall_inserted_rtr) #TODO(sridar): will become a list fw_rtr = fw_rtr_qry.filter_by(fw_id=fwid).first() return fw_rtr def update_fw_rtrs(self, context, fwid, firewall): LOG.debug("update_fw_rtrs() called") with context.session.begin(subtransactions=True): fw_rtr_qry = context.session.query(Firewall_inserted_rtr) #TODO(sridar): again deal with a list of routers fw_rtr = fw_rtr_qry.filter_by(fw_id=fwid).first() fw_rtr.update(firewall) return firewall

commit_message:
Remove usage of remotable context parameter in migration, network

This removes the use of the context parameter in remotable methods
in these objects. This is a precursor to actually removing the
context from the call, but we need to remove dependence on the
argument first. Remotable methods should be using the bundled object
context.

Related to blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: I511080f2980a47c2f2b96150c78609ab79b24b1d

commit_message:
Remove db layer hard-code permission checks for network_get_by_cidr

This patches removes db layer hard-code permission checks for
network_get_by_cidr.

It is called by the follow function:
  1. delete_network in network/manager.py, and context is elevated.
  2. modify in cmd/manage.py, the context is admin context

Partially implements bp v3-api-policy

Change-Id: I0cb02cf1fe5764558441acda5262d2c7928cebf3

commit_message:
Fix some issues with pool name sent to SVC

Add quotes around a pool name so a pool name with
imbedded spaces is a single argument when it arrives
on the SVC

What is happening today is SVC returns a usage
error and fails the request.

Update unit tests to verify quotes where added.

Closes-Bug: 1422903

Change-Id: Ic96304b907913dd8b11a583f03d169f314d851de

commit_message:
Add OS::Trove::Cluster resource

Implements: blueprint trove-cluster-resource

Change-Id: I881ff79daafc85ab0e6fedf39134df3623136874
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/63/159463/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log as logging from heat.common import exception from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.common.i18n import _LI from heat.common.i18n import _LW from heat.engine import attributes from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine import support LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class TroveCluster(resource.Resource): support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='2015.3') TROVE_STATUS = ( ERROR, FAILED, ACTIVE, ) = ( 'ERROR', 'FAILED', 'ACTIVE', ) TROVE_STATUS_REASON = { FAILED: _('The database instance was created, but heat failed to set ' 'up the datastore. If a database instance is in the FAILED ' 'state, it should be deleted and a new one should be ' 'created.'), ERROR: _('The last operation for the database instance failed due to ' 'an error.'), } BAD_STATUSES = (ERROR, FAILED) PROPERTIES = ( NAME, DATASTORE_TYPE, DATASTORE_VERSION, INSTANCES, ) = ( 'name', 'datastore_type', 'datastore_version', 'instances', ) _INSTANCE_KEYS = ( FLAVOR, VOLUME_SIZE, ) = ( 'flavor', 'volume_size', ) ATTRIBUTES = ( INSTANCES_ATTR, ) = ( 'instances', ) properties_schema = { NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Name of the cluster to create.'), constraints=[ constraints.Length(max=255), ] ), DATASTORE_TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Name of registered datastore type."), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.Length(max=255) ] ), DATASTORE_VERSION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _("Name of the registered datastore version. " "It must exist for provided datastore type. " "Defaults to using single active version. " "If several active versions exist for provided datastore type, " "explicit value for this parameter must be specified."), required=True, constraints=[constraints.Length(max=255)] ), INSTANCES: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _("List of database instances"), required=True, schema=properties.Schema( properties.Schema.MAP, schema={ FLAVOR: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Flavor of the instance.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('nova.flavor') ] ), VOLUME_SIZE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('Size of the instance disk volume in GB.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.Range(1, 150), ] ) } ) ) } attributes_schema = { INSTANCES: attributes.Schema( _("A list of instances ids.") ), } default_client_name = 'trove' def _cluster_name(self): name = self.properties(self.NAME) if name: return name return self.physical_resource_name() def handle_create(self): self.datastore_type = self.properties[self.DATASTORE_TYPE] self.datastore_version = self.properties[self.DATASTORE_VERSION] # convert instances to format required by troveclient self.instances = [] for instance in self.properties[self.INSTANCES]: self.instances.append({ 'flavorRef': self.client_plugin().get_flavor_id( instance[self.FLAVOR]), 'volume': {'size': instance[self.VOLUME_SIZE]} }) cluster = self.client().clusters.create( self._cluster_name(), self.datastore_type, self.datastore_version, self.instances) self.resource_id_set(cluster.id) return cluster def _refresh_cluster(self, cluster): try: cluster = self.client().clusters.get(cluster.id) return cluster except Exception as exc: if self.client_plugin().is_over_limit(exc): LOG.warn(_LW("Stack %(name)s (%(id)s) received an " "OverLimit response during clusters.get():" " %(exception)s"), {'name': self.stack.name, 'id': self.stack.id, 'exception': exc}) return cluster else: raise def check_create_complete(self, cluster): cluster = self._refresh_cluster(cluster) for instance in cluster.instances: if instance['status'] in self.BAD_STATUSES: raise resource.ResourceInError( resource_status=instance.status, status_reason=self.TROVE_STATUS_REASON.get( instance['status'], _("Unknown"))) if instance['status'] != self.ACTIVE: return False LOG.info(_LI("Cluster '%s' has been created"), cluster.name) return True def handle_delete(self): if not self.resource_id: return cluster = None try: cluster = self.client().clusters.get(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: cluster.delete() return cluster def check_delete_complete(self, cluster): if not cluster: return True try: # For some time trove cluster may continue to live self._refresh_cluster(cluster) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) return True return False def validate(self): res = super(TroveCluster, self).validate() if res: return res datastore_type = self.properties(self.DATASTORE_TYPE) datastore_version = self.properties(self.DATASTORE_VERSION) if datastore_type: # get current active versions allowed_versions = self.trove().datastore_versions.list( datastore_type) allowed_version_names = [v.name for v in allowed_versions] if datastore_version: if datastore_version not in allowed_version_names: msg = _("Datastore version %(dsversion)s " "for datastore type %(dstype)s is not valid. " "Allowed versions are %(allowed)s.") % { 'dstype': datastore_type, 'dsversion': datastore_version, 'allowed': ', '.join(allowed_version_names)} raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) else: if len(allowed_versions) > 1: msg = _("Multiple active datastore versions exist for " "datastore type %(dstype)s. " "Explicit datastore version must be provided. " "Allowed versions are %(allowed)s.") % { 'dstype': datastore_type, 'allowed': ', '.join(allowed_version_names)} raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) else: if datastore_version: msg = _("Not allowed - %(dsver)s without %(dstype)s.") % { 'dsver': self.DATASTORE_VERSION, 'dstype': self.DATASTORE_TYPE} raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) def _resolve_attribute(self, name): if name == self.INSTANCES_ATTR: instances = [] cluster = self.client().clusters.get(self.resource_id) for instance in cluster.instances: instances.append(instance['id']) return instances def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Trove::Cluster': TroveCluster }

some time in future.

commit_message:
Allow heat-standalone to work with keystone v3

Heat can now run in standalone mode with the default v3 keystone
backend.

This change removes the installation of the v2 contrib backend.
It also configures saner defaults when HEAT_STANDALONE is True.
Using trusts and a stack-domain will never work in standalone mode
since they both require a service user which doesn't exist in
standalone mode.

Finally, this change prevents heat.conf being populated with service user options
not required by standalone mode.

Configuring the v2 backend may be reintroduced later with a dedicated
flag variable.

Change-Id: I88403e359e5e59e776b25ba1b65fae6fa8a3548e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/10/141910/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ "$HEAT_STANDALONE" = "True" ]]; then # for standalone, use defaults which require no service user HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN=`trueorfalse False $HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN` HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH=${HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH:-password} else HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN=`trueorfalse True $HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN` HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH=${HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH:-trusts} fi
deleted_lines: HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN=`trueorfalse True $HEAT_STACK_DOMAIN`HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH=${HEAT_DEFERRED_AUTH:-trusts} if [[ "$HEAT_STANDALONE" = "True" ]]; then setup_develop $HEAT_DIR/contrib/heat_keystoneclient_v2 fi iniset $HEAT_CONF DEFAULT keystone_backend heat_keystoneclient_v2.client.KeystoneClientV2

commit_message:
Remove usage of remotable context parameter in compute_node, keypair

This removes the use of the context parameter in remotable methods
in these objects. This is a precursor to actually removing the
context from the call, but we need to remove dependence on the
argument first. Remotable methods should be using the bundled object
context.

Related to blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: Ia9697e8301606eda3e845ea8e10016f24790ed16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/48/164248/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove usage of remotable context parameter in instance* objects

This removes the use of the context parameter in remotable methods
in these objects. This is a precursor to actually removing the
context from the call, but we need to remove dependence on the
argument first. Remotable methods should be using the bundled object
context.

Related to blueprint kilo-objects

Change-Id: If89e6e03d1e15f8ce688166ff2faa4794280c112

commit_message:
Add the missing "file" keyword for print

All non-keyword arguments are converted to strings and written to
the stream, the argument "sys.stderr" should be given keyword
"file" as keyword argument.

Change-Id: I1f9c4e41ed7a1d3246eae9179fd9221c0a834292
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/40/164740/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: print('Error calling custom handler [%s]' % hook, file=sys.stderr) except ValueError: print('Invalid custom handler format [%s]' % hook, file=sys.stderr)
deleted_lines: print( 'Error calling custom handler [%s]' % hook, file=sys.stderr) except ValueError: print('Invalid custom handler format [%s]' % hook, sys.stderr)

subject: Magnum - OpenStack Containers Service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-18 05:30:09.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/8bf23355ae3f4843b8ae3a2af1145875ef816570', 'message': "Magnum - OpenStack Containers Service

Addition of the Magnum Project - a collaboration of 24 engineers
from 13 affiliations to bring containers to Openstack as a first
class resource. We just concluded our Midcycle meetup.

Magnum builds on Heat to produce Nova instances on which to run
application containers. It is licensed under Apache 2.0, and all
contributors have signed an OpenStack CLA.

All library dependencies allow for unrestricted distribution and
deployment. Our PTL is chosen by our contributors, and holds
weekly IRC meetings in #openstack-meeting-alt and are logged using
Meetbot. We are also available in #openstack-containers to for
daily discussion and as a way for users to converse with our
developers openly.

All Magnum source code is posted to Gerrit, and reviewed. We allow
code merge after two +2 votes. Our code is automatically unit
tested by the OpenStack CI infrastructure. Our PTL serves as a
contact for cross-project teams in OpenStack.

We make extensive use of existing software, and have not
deliberately reproduced functionality that already exists in other
ecosystem projects. Magnum doesn't compete with Swarm, Docker, or
Kubernetes, but instead offers a user experience that integrates
those systems for use with OpenStack. We are open to integrating
best-of-breed technologies that help OpenStack operators offer
application containers to their cloud users.

We have implemented Magnum using the oslo common libraries and
the Pecan+WSME WSGI framework. Magnum completely conforms to the
OpenStack development style.

Project direction has been publically discussed at the Oregon
Nova Midcycle, the Paris OpenStack Design Summit, and in March
2015 at the Magnum Midcycle in San Francisco.

We use the openstack-dev ML for project discussion and do not use
any other mailing lists.

Magnum is compatible with OpenStack APIs, and uses Keystone
middleware to integrate with OpenStack Identity. All per-tenant
Magnum infrastructure is deployed using OpenStack Orchestration
using HOT files.

There are numerous active contributors from several affiliations
who have allocated full-time engineers to contribute to Magnum.

Magnum is different from Nova, because it provides a purpose built
API to manage application containers, which have a distinctly
different lifecycle and operations than Nova (machine) Instances.

Magnum is also different from Docker and Kubernetes, by offering
an asynchronous REST API that's compatible with Keystone, and a
complete multi-tenancy implementation. It does not perform
orchestration internally, and instead relies on OpenStack
Orchestration.

Change-Id: Ib1e28dca958e0cdc2b84460cef70744788fec2b0
"}]
commit_message:
Magnum - OpenStack Containers Service

Addition of the Magnum Project - a collaboration of 24 engineers
from 13 affiliations to bring containers to Openstack as a first
class resource. We just concluded our Midcycle meetup.

Magnum builds on Heat to produce Nova instances on which to run
application containers. It is licensed under Apache 2.0, and all
contributors have signed an OpenStack CLA.

All library dependencies allow for unrestricted distribution and
deployment. Our PTL is chosen by our contributors, and holds
weekly IRC meetings in #openstack-meeting-alt and are logged using
Meetbot. We are also available in #openstack-containers to for
daily discussion and as a way for users to converse with our
developers openly.

All Magnum source code is posted to Gerrit, and reviewed. We allow
code merge after two +2 votes. Our code is automatically unit
tested by the OpenStack CI infrastructure. Our PTL serves as a
contact for cross-project teams in OpenStack.

We make extensive use of existing software, and have not
deliberately reproduced functionality that already exists in other
ecosystem projects. Magnum doesn't compete with Swarm, Docker, or
Kubernetes, but instead offers a user experience that integrates
those systems for use with OpenStack. We are open to integrating
best-of-breed technologies that help OpenStack operators offer
application containers to their cloud users.

We have implemented Magnum using the oslo common libraries and
the Pecan+WSME WSGI framework. Magnum completely conforms to the
OpenStack development style.

Project direction has been publically discussed at the Oregon
Nova Midcycle, the Paris OpenStack Design Summit, and in March
2015 at the Magnum Midcycle in San Francisco.

We use the openstack-dev ML for project discussion and do not use
any other mailing lists.

Magnum is compatible with OpenStack APIs, and uses Keystone
middleware to integrate with OpenStack Identity. All per-tenant
Magnum infrastructure is deployed using OpenStack Orchestration
using HOT files.

There are numerous active contributors from several affiliations
who have allocated full-time engineers to contribute to Magnum.

Magnum is different from Nova, because it provides a purpose built
API to manage application containers, which have a distinctly
different lifecycle and operations than Nova (machine) Instances.

Magnum is also different from Docker and Kubernetes, by offering
an asynchronous REST API that's compatible with Keystone, and a
complete multi-tenancy implementation. It does not perform
orchestration internally, and instead relies on OpenStack
Orchestration.

Change-Id: Ib1e28dca958e0cdc2b84460cef70744788fec2b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/98/165298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Get external images for a deployment.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-12-11 12:42:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/8194487df0e506e88eab27fbeb61733291cabf6a', 'message': 'Get external images for a deployment.

Using the  acquire-image script, we can cache locally images from an
external repository where they have been already built.

This time, it is NOT embedded in the devtest logic, and should be used
before building the images.

Usage:
acquire-image --download DOWNLOAD_URL [options] IMAGE_SET
where options can be --help and -c (check for local copies).

The metadata file, IMAGE_SET.meta is a json file with the following
structure:

{"images": [
  "seed.qcow2",
  "tripleo_undercloud.qcow2",
  "tripleo_overcloud.qcow2",
  ...
]}

The image provider can have several images collections (scale vs. no_scale,
fedora vs. ubuntu, amd64 vs i386), so the clients can use the most
suitable for them.

Change-Id: I20858c4201caf45d46e098503fff7759af2cc34f
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-12-16 12:10:35.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator/commit/86303222702bb376b065b69cd5abe99fa5c18b6d', 'message': 'Get external images for a deployment.

before building the images.

Usage:
acquire-image --download DOWNLOAD_URL [options] IMAGE_SET
where options can be --help and -c (check for local copies).

The metadata file, IMAGE_SET, is a json file with the following
structure:

{"images": [
  "image1_control.qcow2",
  "image2_compute.qcow2",
  "image3_compute_ha.qcow2",
  ...
]}

The image provider can have several images collections (scale vs. no_scale,
fedora vs. ubuntu, amd64 vs i386), so the clients can use the most
suitable for them.

Change-Id: I20858c4201caf45d46e098503fff7759af2cc34f
'}]
commit_message:
Get external images for a deployment.

Using the acquire-image script, we can cache locally images from an
external repository where they have been already built.

This time, it is NOT embedded in the devtest logic, and should be used
before building the images.

Usage:
acquire-image --download DOWNLOAD_URL [options] IMAGE_SET
where options can be --help and -c (check for local copies).

The metadata file, IMAGE_SET, is a json file with the following
structure:

{"images": [
  "image1_control.qcow2",
  "image2_compute.qcow2",
  "image3_compute_ha.qcow2",
  ...
]}

The image provider can have several images collections (scale vs. no_scale,
fedora vs. ubuntu, amd64 vs i386), so the clients can use the most
suitable for them.

Change-Id: I20858c4201caf45d46e098503fff7759af2cc34f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/38/141038/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash set -eu set -o pipefail SCRIPT_NAME=$(basename $0) SCRIPT_HOME=$(dirname $0) function show_options () { echo "Usage: $SCRIPT_NAME --download BASE_URL [options] IMAGE_NAME" echo echo "Acquire an image from cache/download it." echo echo "A download root need to be supplied and the image will be downloaded only if" echo "the local copy is different. With -c, locally built images are not refreshed" echo "while we can do cache invalidation for downloaded images, we don't have cache" echo "invalidation logic yet for building images - -c allows direct control." echo echo "What constitutes an image is determined by the images key of the" echo "\$IMAGE_NAME.meta metadata file." echo echo "Options:" echo " -c -- re-use existing images rather than rebuilding." echo " --download BASE_URL -- download images from BASE_URL/\$imagename." echo " -h, --help -- this text." echo exit $1 } DOWNLOAD_BASE= USE_CACHE= TEMP=$(getopt -o ch -l download:,help -n $SCRIPT_NAME -- "$@") if [ $? != 0 ] ; then echo "Terminating..." >&2 ; exit 1 ; fi # Note the quotes around `$TEMP': they are essential! eval set -- "$TEMP" while true ; do case "$1" in --download) DOWNLOAD_BASE=$2; shift 2;; -c) USE_CACHE=1; shift 1;; -h | --help) show_options 0;; --) shift ; break ;; *) echo "Error: unsupported option $1." ; exit 1 ;; esac done IMAGE_SET=${1:-''} shift if [ -z "$IMAGE_SET" -o -z "$DOWNLOAD_BASE" ]; then show_options 1 fi IMAGE_BASENAME=$(basename "${IMAGE_SET}") IMAGE_DIRNAME=$(dirname "${IMAGE_SET}") URL_BASENAME=$DOWNLOAD_BASE/$IMAGE_BASENAME METADATA_PATH=$URL_BASENAME.meta CACHE_URL="$TRIPLEO_ROOT/diskimage-builder/elements/cache-url/bin/cache-url" if [ image_exists -a -n "$USE_CACHE" ]; then exit 0 fi set +e "${CACHE_URL}" ${METADATA_PATH} ${IMAGE_SET}.meta RES=$? set -e if [ 0 -ne "$RES" -a 44 -ne "$RES" ]; then exit $RES elif [ 44 -ne "$RES" ]; then IMG_LIST=$(jq '.images' ${IMAGE_SET}.meta) for pos in $(seq 0 $(( $(jq length <<< $IMG_LIST) -1 )) ); do COMPONENT_NAME=$(jq -r ".[$pos]" <<< $IMG_LIST) "${CACHE_URL}" ${DOWNLOAD_BASE}/${COMPONENT_NAME} "${IMAGE_DIRNAME}"/${COMPONENT_NAME} done exit 0 fi function image_exists() { if [ ! -e "${IMAGE_SET}.meta" ]; then return 1 fi IMG_LIST=$(jq '.images' ${IMAGE_SET}.meta) for pos in $(seq 0 $(($(jq length <<< $IMG_LIST) -1))); do COMPONENT_NAME=$(jq -r ".[$pos]" <<< $IMG_LIST) if [ ! -e "${IMAGE_DIRNAME}"/${COMPONENT_NAME} ]; then return 1 fi done return 0 }

commit_message:
LBaaS reference implementation driver to support TLS

Including plugin modifications for barbican container retrieval
Including template updates to support TLS and SNI
Including jinja_config updates to support storing of the container details
Including driver updates for data directory locations

Implement blueprint lbaas-ref-impl-tls-support

Change-Id: Ie6d09780bc6e617ca2be15ee2378f7f51f08218d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/51/145151/14 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
def test_get_template(self): def test_render_template_tls(self): fe = ("frontend sample_listener_id_1
" " option tcplog
" " maxconn 98
" " bind 10.0.0.2:80 " "crt /v2/sample_loadbalancer_id_1/cont_id_1.pem " "crt /v2/sample_loadbalancer_id_1
" " mode tcp
" " default_backend sample_pool_id_1

") be = ("backend sample_pool_id_1
" " mode tcp
" " balance roundrobin
" " cookie SRV insert indirect nocache
" " timeout check 31
" " option httpchk GET /index.html
" " http-check expect rstatus 405|404|500
" " option ssl-hello-chk

commit_message:
Remove configure_cinder_backend_conf_lvm

Setting the local device filter like we were doing here
doesn't actually solve the problem.  We actually need to
set a global filter.

Submitted change: I5d5c48e188cbb9b4208096736807f082bce524e8

Once that lands this code won't be necessary at all and should
be removed.  We'll also remove the local conf usage in Cinder,
but currently that's harmless as it's designed to detect if
the local lvm.conf file exists in the cinder directory and
behave appropriately based on it's existence.

Change-Id: Iba701a8cb00ef7ce5acd675e8714ad471fb4cb37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/82/165282/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: local has_lvm=0 if [[ $be_type == 'lvm' ]]; then has_lvm=1 fi # Keep it simple, set a marker if there's an LVM backend # use the created VG's to setup lvm filters if [[ $has_lvm == 1 ]]; then # Order matters here, not only obviously to make # sure the VG's are created, but also some distros # do some customizations to lvm.conf on init, we # want to make sure we copy those over sudo cp /etc/lvm/lvm.conf /etc/cinder/lvm.conf configure_cinder_backend_conf_lvm fi

commit_message:
Add uefi support for agent iscsi deploy

This commit adds uefi support for agent iscsi
deploy using pxe_* and iscsi_ilo drivers.
The image.install_bootloader extension in agent
now accepts a new parameter efi_system_part_uuid
which will be used for boot loader installation in
uefi boot mode.  We identify the efi system partition's
uuid after deploying the image and pass this information
to agent ramdisk while installing boot loader.

Depends-On: I8fbb4b2ebdff991d41c7b618a4d654af26311a56
Implements: blueprint local-boot-support-with-partition-images
Change-Id: Ic7337fa1b0a5aefd3137b754acc88c547fc7e9e2

commit_message:
Fixes misspelling in ch_creating_images_manually

In text: "The following example shows how to use the qemu-img
command to create an empty image file virt-install command to
start up a virtual machine using that image file".

Seems to have to be: "The following example shows how to use
the qemu-img command to create an empty image file, and
virt-install command to start up a virtual machine using
that image file" ("and" missed).

Change-Id: I3a4dc48261403a205b3ab80cbf98ab730b2689f5
Closes-bug: #1431290

commit_message:
Describe API endpoints in "Create the service entity and API" page

The Install Guide has a page which lists instructions for creating
the API endpoints. It mentions the public, admin, and internal API
endpoints, and mentions that they might be on separate networks for
security reasons, but there is no description of the differences
between the endpoints. This change adds description of the API
endpoints and lists examples of the networks that might be used.
The latest patchset tightens up one sentence as suggested in the
comments of patchset 1.

Change-Id: I8bcf1a765d187919c3f5718e24d1e362723f36db
Closes-Bug: #1432801
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/43/164843/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: admin, internal, and public. The admin API endpoint allows modifying users and tenants by default, while the public API and internal API do not. In a production environment, the variants might reside on separate networks that service different types of users for security reasons. For instance, the public API network might be reachable from outside the cloud for management tools, the admin API network might be protected, while the internal API network is connected to each host. Also, OpenStack supports multiple regions for scalability. For simplicity, this configuration uses the management network for all endpoint variations and the <literal>regionOne</literal> region.</para>
deleted_lines: admin, internal, and public. In a production environment, the variants might reside on separate networks that service different types of users for security reasons. Also, OpenStack supports multiple regions for scalability. For simplicity, this configuration uses the management network for all endpoint variations and the <literal>regionOne</literal> region.</para>

commit_message:
Removed misleading SPBM section

The section implied that you could use SPBM for the datastore backend
but this is incorrect. So pursuant to the bug, I removed the section.

Change-Id: If023d5644c8bb4e7361bf7434305f2f2de44fff5
backport: juno
Closes-Bug: #:1426566
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/42/165242/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: <para>Alternatively, you can specify a SPBM policy, which can comprise multiple vCenter data stores. Both approaches are described.</para> <note> <para>SPBM requires vCenter Server 5.5 or later.</para> </note> <procedure> <title>To configure multiple data stores using SPBM</title> <step> <para>In vCenter, use tagging to identify the data stores and define a storage policy:</para> <substeps> <step> <para>Create the tag.</para> </step> <step> <para>Apply the tag to the data stores to be used by the SPBM policy.</para> </step> <step> <para>Create a tag-based storage policy that uses one or more tags to identify a set of data stores.</para> </step> </substeps> <note> <para>For details about creating tags in vSphere, see the <link xlink:href="http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-55/index.jsp#com.vmware.vsphere.vcenterhost.doc/GUID-379F40D3-8CD6-449E-89CB-79C4E2683221.html">vSphere documentation</link>. </para> <para>For details about storage policies in vSphere, see the <link xlink:href="http://pubs.vmware.com/vsphere-55/index.jsp#com.vmware.vsphere.storage.doc/GUID-A8BA9141-31F1-4555-A554-4B5B04D75E54.html">vSphere documentation</link>. </para> </note> </step> <step> <para>Return to the <filename>glance-api.conf</filename> file.</para> </step> <step> <para>Comment or delete the <option>vmware_datastore_name</option> parameter.</para> </step> <step> <para>Uncomment and define the <option>vmware_pbm_policy</option> parameter by entering the same value as the tag you defined and applied to the data stores in vCenter.</para> </step> <step> <para>Uncomment and define the <option>vmware_pbm_wsdl_location</option> parameter by entering the location of the PBM service WSDL file. For example, <filename>file:///opt/SDK/spbm/wsdl/pbmService.wsdl</filename>.</para> <note> <para>If you do not set this parameter, the storage policy cannot be used to place images in the data store.</para> </note> <para>Complete the other vCenter configuration parameters as appropriate.</para> </step> </procedure>
